title: Wednesday, 1st November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Hello! Welcome, hi there.

BE11:05am

But before we get to it, have a picture I forgot to share yesterday.

BE11:05am

11:04 am
BE11:05am

Truly terrifying.

BE11:05am

Seems that as an individual user you're permitted to view of the pumpkin strictly on a one-month trial basis, but there's a fee required if you want to light the candle.

BE11:06am

(And thanks to the person who sent that over.)

11:05 am
BE11:06am

More to the point .....

BE11:06am

BE11:06am

Today's the day! End of an era, probably.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

As in, an 80% probability of a 25bp hike.

BE11:06am

Decision midday (which we'll be on air for), conference to follow at 12.30 (which we won't).

BE11:08am

And we may as well get the ducks in a row for tomorrow's decision. Consensus is a 6-3 vote, FWIW.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Here's that chart above panned out to the 1970s.

BE11:09am

BE11:09am

You'll see the last rate hike was back in July 2007.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Same week as the smoking ban came into force in England .... Rihanna's Umbrella was #1 on the pop parade.... Lehman Brothers was trading at around $80 a share .... and Alphaville was less than eight months old.

BE11:10am

So this is the last day of free-ish money! (Probably)/ Enjoy it while it lasts.

undefined
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Anyway, rather than pan forward we should move onto this morning's happenings.

BE11:11am

Starting with drugs.

Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 405.57, up 33.96 (+9.14%), High: 416.70, Low: 401.40, Volume: 2.26m
11:12 am
BE11:12am

FDA's done exactly what was expected and recommended Indivior's once-a-day injection thing.

BE11:13am

In fact, it's a bit more positive than expected.

BE11:14am

Trials for efficacy backed by 17 panellists, with only 2 no's.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Higher dose safety gets 13 yes and six no, which is unexpected.

BE11:15am

And approval was 18 to one.

BE11:15am

We knew things looked positive from the 60-odd pages of briefing notes released earlier in the week, but this is still pretty good news.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Here's Numis.

BE11:16am

The panel clearly favoured the lower dose,
with more data and/or post approval studies needed to better validate the safety and optimal patient groups for the higher dose. The overwhelming message from physicians and patients during the meeting was the need for new treatment options to address the escalating opioid crisis, and we now expect FDA approval by the end of November and commercial launch in early 2018. This recommendation for approval significantly de-risks the longer-term investment case, and our target price thus increases to 640p, based on de-risking future cash-flow due to a more normalised discount rate and the assumption of generic film in 2018.

BE11:16am

The key discussion now, is the likely market penetration and pricing of RBP-6000, where we see plenty of elasticity. At $11k per year, the drug would be priced in line with schizophrenia monthlies and need 8% share for a billion-dollars in sales. At half the price, 16% share is not inconceivable. Either way the extension of Indivior’s prospects beyond Suboxone film has now been secured, and based primarily on a DCF analysis we up our target price to 640p, which factors in generic film in 2018.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

A sidebar here is Camrus's CAM2038.

BE11:18am

A rival Buprenorphine injection treatment.

BE11:18am

FDA's meeting later today on that. And it's not looking so promising.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Here's Stifel.

BE11:19am

Our review of the FDA briefing documents
suggests that whilst there are no major safety or efficacy concerns raised for the
drug CAM2038 itself, the studies conducted by Camurus and its US marketing partner Braeburn have not adequately demonstrated the profile of the drug at its multiple doses. The Phase III trial design did also not follow the FDA's recommendation and as such is likely not to get as favourable a FDA review as RBP-6000 received. To quote the FDA briefing documents 'The data were presented in a manner that dose not facilitate the determination of whether all the studied doses were effective'. The FDA raised similar concerns about the amount of safety data on certain of the CAM2038 doses.

BE11:19am

Upside to RBP-6000 if CAM2038 is delayed. If approval of CAM2038 were delayed we believe this would significantly benefit sales of RBP-6000. If further studies are required by the FDA for CAM2038, we estimate this could delay its approval by at least two years. At present we continue to forecast sales of RBP-6000 of $707m by 2021E assuming a launch of CAM2038 by 19 January 2018 (the pdufa date).

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Consensus for peak annual sales for RBP6k runs from about $800m to about $1.4bn, I think, with Merrill towards the bottom of that and RBC at the top.

BE11:22am

Here's RBC from a day or two ago.

BE11:22am

Our 77 physician survey collected more than 1600 data points covering patients per prescriber, products currently utilised, rationale for prescribing, potential penetration of a long acting (LA) product over time, perceived benefits of a LA product and the risk of a generic Film on these prescribing habits. Our survey suggests LA products could take 39% patient share (35% within 6-months) with no physician indicating that they wouldn’t prescribe a LA product at one year. However, the launch of a generic Film could see a meaningful (c30%) impact on prescriber habits, and hence on the market value of a LA product.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Whilst it appears the take-up of a LA product
could be quick we see pricing/reimbursement questions alongside practical/logistical reasons to suggest a slower ramp. Taking all this into consideration we see peak sales of $1.4bn by 2023 as possible but more should i) improvements in compliance lead to larger patient numbers, ii) no generic Film or iii) CAM-2038 be delayed. We put through minor forecast changes, but increase our valuation to 500p from 470p given the greater confidence in the RBP-6000 commercial opportunity.

undefined
BE11:24am

What else, then? I guess we can come to Smurfit later, if we must.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Best get retail out of the way though.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 4,524, down 397.02 (-8.07%), High: 4,707, Low: 4,500, Volume: 1.46m
BE11:26am

(@doeswalk: sorry, should have made it clearer at the top that eras don't start and end on the same day. Today is indeed Wednesday.)

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Sales weak, again.

BE11:27am

Both retail and brand, though directory is okay.

BE11:27am

Except that's off a very low comparative, so isn't really impressive either.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

The help of colder weather in August and September seems to have tailed off at the back of the month

BE11:28am

All of which results in a tightening of full year guidance

BE11:29am

Total yoy full price sales goes to -1.75% to +1.25%, from -2% to +1.5% previously.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

PBT goes to £692m-£742m from £687m-£747m previously, which is versus a £723m consensus.

BE11:30am

Have Morgan Stanley to summarise.

BE11:30am

As expected the group's sales growth came entirely from the Directory division, where sales were up 13.2% (vs a consensus expectation of +12.0%). Sales in the Retail division continue to decline: they were down 7.7% (slightly worse than consensus of -3.7%), despite the addition of new space. LfL sales were not disclosed, but they are likely to have been down around 11% in Retail.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

The statement includes a chart of sales performance during the quarter. It shows clearly that, after a strong performance in August and September, sales slowed sharply in October. Given unfavourable weather conditions and a tougher comparative, the October slowdown should not come as much of a surprise. Nevertheless it is clearly unhelpful for sentiment that the 'exit rate' from the quarter is so weak.

BE11:31am

We suspect that there will also be some disappointment that the company has decided to leave the midpoint of its profit guidance range for the year unchanged. At the Interim results last month the company raised both the top and bottom end of its guidance range by £7m, stating that it expected Pre Tax Profits for FY 2017/18 to be between £687m and £747m (giving a mid point of £717m). Today management tightened this range slightly to £692m - £742m, but the mid-point remains unchanged. Going into today, the consensus average profit expectation was £722m (according to Bloomberg) and we doubt that it will change much today.

BE11:31am

Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Next is
trading on 12.4x Cal 2018 earnings, 9.4x EBITDA with a 3.5% Dividend Yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.8x, 8.1x and 4.1% respectively.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

And JP Morgan.

BE11:32am

This is a softer than expected trading update from Next: full price Brand sales are a miss versus consensus (driven by a -10% LFL decline in Retail); the mid-point of FY 18 guidance is unchanged (versus expectations for a nudge upwards); and management is reminding us of tough comparatives in the final quarter of the year. Furthermore, whilst Directory is a touch ahead of consensus, it is nevertheless a slowdown on a 2-year stack basis, suggesting that performance remains weather-driven rather than due to underlying improvements in the business (recall this had been a source of optimism at the H1 stage). Whilst weak Clothing market sales in October (driven by warmer temperatures) had already been highlighted by John Lewis and BDO data, the magnitude of the step-down is greater than we had thought, which also reads negatively for the rest of the sector.

BE11:32am

Indeed.

11:32 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 325.60, down 18.5 (-5.38%), High: 334.60, Low: 324.00, Volume: 7.94m
Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 42.25, down 1.5 (-3.43%), High: 43.00, Low: 40.75, Volume: 2.69m
BE11:04am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing. So, big day.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

(Does weather affect sales of mobile phones and fridges? Perhaps it does.)

undefined
BE11:34am

IMPERIAL BRANDS IS SAID TO BUY U.K. VAPING SUPPLIER NERUDIA

11:34 am
BE11:34am

That's per Bloomberg.

Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,097, up 26 (+0.85%), High: 3,102, Low: 3,065, Volume: 747.22k
BE11:35am

IMB management flagged up acquisitions at its recent capital markets day, if I remember correctly.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Which the market took as "another year of transition" and promptly sold it off.

BE11:36am

And looks like Neruda is e-liquids rather than heat-not-burn, where Imperial has nothing. http://nerudia.com...services/nicotine/

BE11:38am

"Confidentiality is our top product," says its website, which is a slightly unsettling thing to boast about given the history of tobacco companies and their confidentiality policies. http://nerudia.com/about-us/

11:38 am
undefined
BE11:40am

Back up there among the retail stuff, I should have remembered to mention that Liberum's gone to "sell" on Debenhams.

Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 42.25, down 1.5 (-3.43%), High: 43.00, Low: 40.75, Volume: 2.70m
11:40 am
BE11:40am

We revisit Debenhams’ investment case post the prelims and downgrade to SELL on a reduced 40p TP. Looking past the low current rating (CY18E PER 8.4x), we focus on the fundamentals, which do not enthuse us. Ongoing structural challenges, a soft consumer environment, rising costs and increasing capex demands make for a difficult outlook, in our view. Our EPS forecasts sit 5% to 8% below current consensus over FY18E-20E, implying a CAGR of -4.6%.

BE11:40am

Mid-market department stores are being squeezed by more premium players, specialists and online. We acknowledge the progress under the new CEO, but turning 13m sq. ft. into ‘destination’ space is tough. Material closures/right-sizing will take time.

BE11:41am

Where does the destination thing stand right now? Gyms, wasn't it?

11:41 am
BE11:42am

In addition to chain restaurants and trainer concessions.

BE11:43am

I'm of the opinion that you'll never be a destination when getting into the place involves running the gauntlet of makeup demonstrators and perfume sprayers, but what do I know? Back to Liberum.

BE11:43am

FY07-17 capex amounted to £1.3bn or 2.4x current market cap. FY18E-21E total spend of c.£590m will again exceed the group’s current equity value to achieve an EPS CAGR of
-0.8% on consensus forecasts. FCF will fall materially over the period.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

We forecast DPS to drop 15% in FY18E to 2.9p, implying 1.8x cover (EPS) vs. management's 2.0x target. On a FCF basis, the DPS will be uncovered (0.3x) and if accelerated investment is required under the turnaround strategy this would place further pressure on the dividend.

BE11:43am

Our new TP of 40p implies a CY18E PER of 7.6x, a dividend yield of 7.3% and a FCF yield of 3.2%, rising to 8.3% by CY20E. The shares are down 23% YTD to trade on a CY18E PER of 8.4x, but we fear a value trap. Earnings visibility is low and the downgrade cycle could well extend.

undefined
11:45 am
BE11:45am

(@Chopper: https://www.ft.com...-9bfb-4a9c83ffa852 )

BE11:45am

(Beyond that, we know nowt.)

BE11:47am

Rather a lot of stuff around Inmarsat this morning, none of which seems to be helping it.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Morgan Stanley, for instance, has quite a thing out that discusses space.

BE11:48am

Couple of screens from that, to give you the flavour.

BE11:49am

11:49 am
BE11:49am

BE11:50am

BE11:50am

11:50 am
BE11:51am

I like it when analysis features big bags of money with dollar signs on it. Really brings home the argument.

BE11:52am

Anyway, here's the investment list.

BE11:52am

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Of more relevance we have Inmarsat Q3s coming up shortly.

BE11:54am

Key swing here is whether Maritime turns the corner and moves back into growth, even just sequentially.

BE11:54am

RBC reckons, "no".

11:54 am
BE11:54am

We expect an improvement in Maritime trends with 3Q down -1.9% vs -5.0% in 2Q due to 1) easier comps and 2) growing VSAT revenues driven by sub growth. Longer term, ISAT will likely see continued Fleet Broadband sub decline. However this is due to internal migration - at the lower end to Fleet One and at the top end to Fleet Xpress. In our view the key to maritime growth is the installation backlog of c.10,000 Fleet Xpress ships (vs a current base of 1,137), many of which will be new to Inmarsat. Government: We expect ISAT to post a 5.0% growth in Government helped by the Boeing take-or-pay contract, the CSSC contract (since early April) and operational activity related to relief work. Aviation: We expect a 31% growth in revenue driven by SwiftBroadband adoption and the start of Inflight Connectivity.

BE11:55am

Also note we've had Eutelsat and SES both warn and, while the overlap is far from perfect, it's not a great sign either.

BE11:56am

(@FJP: think Wilton Fry is lead analyst of four, including Jon.)

11:56 am
undefined
BE11:57am

Demands for Smurfit comment. Happy to help. Well, happy-ish.

Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 2,331, up 87 (+3.88%), High: 2,341, Low: 2,240, Volume: 358.98k
11:57 am
BE11:58am

Merrill with the micro-sum.

BE11:58am

Q3 EBITDA right inline EUR320mn, same as cons. Guides for FY17E EBITDA in line with market expectations. Positive commentary. Continued box price recovery re-assuring. Think this should result in margin expansion in 2018. Like: 1) Strong FCF generations. 2) Exposure to E-commerce/value-add packaging. 3) Attractive valuation 6.6x FY18E EBITDA.

BE11:58am

Citi with the context.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Implications — The company states that it is on track to meet market expectations for the full year, suggesting that it expects no material change to consensus on the back of these numbers. We think the market will find today’s results as fairly solid, but uninspiring, with discussing at this morning’s analyst call focusing on the degree to which corrugated price rises are able to pass through continued high input costs.

BE11:59am

Davy on the balance sheet.

BE11:59am

SKG generated free cash flow of €152m in the period, representing almost 50% conversion from EBITDA. This was despite a working capital inflow of just €5m compared to €51m in Q3 2016. Higher raw material, containerboard and corrugated prices resulted in higher levels of working capital, with the ratio to sales increasing to over 8%. The company spent €36m in M&A in the period, which presumably reflects the consideration for the Russian packaging business. The company also announced the acquisition of a display and corrugated business in Greece in October for an undisclosed sum. We believe this could be of a similar magnitude to the Russian deal. Net debt/EBITDA declined to 2.3x at end-September from 2.5x at the end of Q2.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

And UBS with bottom line.

BE12:00pm

In-line statement should be supportive for the stock given concerns post the recent slight reduction in guidance at Mondi.

undefined
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

On ITV, mentioned right ............

BE12:02pm

Haven't really heard anything specific beyond the sector stuff ......

BE12:02pm

As in, WPP and retailers as proxies for ad spend trends, plus Liberty's recent comments about the UK being an absolute crapshow at the moment.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Exane's William Packer has a quite cautious update out on ITV this morning, from a sector view.

BE12:03pm

Our survey data finds that (especially among younger consumers): i) linear TV continues to lose share of audience to online; and ii) OTT providers are set to maintain strong growth. This in our view brings elevated risk to the incumbent economics as i) OTT content quality and customer satisfaction continue to rise, bringing elevated risk of pay-TV ARPU / subscriber cannibalisation;
and ii) GAFA pressure TV ad market share.

BE12:03pm

We continue to argue ITV NAR weakness reflects structural pressure from GAFA, rather than
Brexit-related macro (as seen in much of EU FTA TV). We expect Q3 NAR could surprise on the
upside (17 Nov. release) but are cautious on Q4 exit momentum. We remain sceptical on material
retrans fees post channel checks. With new CEO Carolyn McCall starting in early 2018, we see
reinvestment risks in programming costs, ITV’s Online presence and potential Studios restructuring as she looks to reaccelerate anaemic growth. However, at 10.6x P/E 18e, valuation is supportive.

12:04 pm
undefined
BE12:06pm

So anyway, are we done here? The final session of the new normal, ahead of tomorrow's new new normal?

BE12:07pm

Do join us tomorrow for an entire hour of arguing about tightening cycles and one-and-done, most likely.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Enjoy your Wednesday. Afternoon all.

Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 169.40, down 4 (-2.31%), High: 173.90, Low: 168.40, Volume: 1.44m
